chapter.htmlHeader: What is the prognosis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
The majority of people with confirmed coeliac disease report a rapid improvement in symptoms after starting a gluten-free diet, and have a normal life expectancy [Mooney, 2014a; NICE, 2015a].

  • The resolution of symptoms of coeliac disease does not necessarily correlate with the degree of duodenal mucosal recovery.
    • A European Society for the Study of Coeliac Disease guideline cites studies showing that in people adhering to a strict gluten-free diet for more than 1 year, up to 75% had remission of symptoms and biopsies showed normal villous architecture, but 50–70% still had signs of mucosal damage (increased intraepithelial lymphocytes) [Al-Toma, 2019].
  • 'Slow responders' describes the 7–30% of adults with coeliac disease who continue to have persistent symptoms, signs, or laboratory abnormalities of coeliac disease despite a gluten-free diet for at least 6–12 months [Al-Toma, 2019].
    • Expert opinion in a review article defines 'slow responders' as people with progressive improvement in symptoms and mucosal damage, but full remission does not occur for at least 1–2 years [Caio, 2019].
  • 'Non-responsive coeliac disease' refers to people with persistent symptoms and enteropathy that do not respond after 6–12 months on a self-reported gluten-free diet, and is most commonly due to inadvertent gluten ingestion [Cichewicz, 2019; McAllister, 2019].
    • The British Society of Gastroenterology guidelines suggest that 4–30% of people with coeliac disease report persisting symptoms and are considered to be non-responsive [Ludvigsson, 2014].
  • 'Refractory coeliac disease' refers to people with persistent or recurrence of otherwise unexplained malabsorption symptoms and villous atrophy on duodenal biopsy, despite strict adherence to a gluten-free diet for at least 12 months [Mooney, 2014a; Al-Toma, 2019; Caio, 2019].
    • About 10% of people with non-responsive coeliac disease may have refractory disease [NICE, 2015b].
    • It is mostly diagnosed after the age of 50 years, and incidence rates range from 0.04 to 1.5% [Al-Toma, 2019].
    • There are two subtypes, and the high mortality associated with type II disease is due to nutritional complications and the higher risk of transformation into enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma (EATL), which occurs in 33–52% of cases within 5 years after diagnosis [Ludvigsson, 2014; Al-Toma, 2019; Caio, 2019].
  • People with coeliac disease display possible excess mortality compared with the general population, but the evidence in the literature is conflicting, and there is no consensus of opinion [McAllister, 2019]. A UK primary care cohort study of cause-specific mortality for people with coeliac disease (n = 10,825) found [Abdul Sultan, 2015]:
    • The overall mortality rate among people with coeliac disease was 128 per 10,000 person-years, compared with 153 per 10,000 in controls (hazard ratio 0.94).
    • People with coeliac disease had 0.15% excess risk of deaths from non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma from the general population baseline risk, up to 10 years post-diagnosis.
    • People with coeliac disease had no major excess risk of cancer, gastrointestinal or respiratory disease-related or cardiovascular-related mortality compared with the general population, up to 10 years post-diagnosis.
